unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Finding the P-value of a 1-sided When Given a 2-sided P-value
question_text:
A two-sided hypothesis test obtained a $p$-value of $0.36$.
If the test was conducted as a one-tailed test using the same set of data, which of the following is true about the possible $p$-values that could have been acquired?
solution:
In a normal distribution, a two-sided test indicates half of $0.36$ is in each tail, meaning $0.18$. Please see the picture below.



This question tells us that it is one-sided, but not in which direction. Let us assume we are in the left tail. Since we do not know the direction of the one-sided test, we must assume the direction can either be less than or greater than.

Figuring out the less-than component in the left tail is the easier one. Taking half of $0.36$, we get $0.18$. Please see the picture below.



Figuring out the greater-than component in the left tail is a little bit more challenging.

Since $0.18$ or $18\%$ is the cutoff in the left tail then we must figure out how much area is to the right of the cutoff. In a normal distribution, the area under the curve is $1$. Therefore $1-0.18=0.82$.



The possible $p$-values are $0.18$ and $0.82$.

This matches Choice 'E'.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect as this is only one of two possible answers.

Choice 'B' is incorrect as this is merely the $p$-value doubled, which does not help determine the possible p-value.

Choice 'C' is incorrect as this only one of the two possible $p$-values.

Choice 'D' is incorrect as this has one of the choices as the $p$-value doubled or incorrectly subtracted from $1.0$.
